subject: Oh, the Humanity!
event:
Well, I spent several hours on the phone yesterday, talking with my local computer guru, my Australian computer guru, and two different service consultants at AOL (from India or Bangladesh would be my guess, judging from their accents).  We tried many different things, some several times, but in the end nothing worked.  My emails and bookmarks are still gone.  It is now starting to look pretty certain that they are lost for good, although there are a few last-ditch things I want to try before I give up completely.

In a way this is a sort of liberation, as I said in my last post here... but it still has me bummed out.  Every time I think I have started to put it behind me, I remember another particular bit of email -- incoming, out-going, or waiting to be finished -- that is now lost to me, and I get morose all over again.  It's a rotten way to start the year.

I am doing a lot of thinking, however.  I have to make some serious changes in the ways I handle email.  As traumatic as this loss has been, it was ridiculous that I ever allowed myself to get into a position where I HAD more than three thousand unanswered emails in my filing cabinet.  Some of them dated as far back as 1998 (the last time AOL treated me to one of these crashes, and wiped out my files).  I kept them because, well... many of them were long, thoughtful, moving emails from my readers than I felt deserved replies, and I kept telling myself that one day I would reply to them, but then...

The problem did not occur overnight, of course.  There must have been a time in 1998 when I had only ten unanswered emails.  And that night I answered five of them, and the next day ten new ones came in, and... well, I did my best to keep up, by fits and starts, but I could never quite do it, even when I resorted to half a dozen different form letters, so over the years I just started falling further and further behind.  At one point in 2004, I recall, the number had climbed to over 2500, and I got alarmed and girded up my loins (painful, that) and by hook and by crook got it down under 1600 in less than a month.  Then I went away on a trip, and by the time I came back it was over 2500 again.

Of course, I shouldn't give the impression that all of the mails I lost were fan letters.  Far from it.  I also had personal correspondence in there, hobby stuff, and lots and lots of business emails.  I need a better way to handle those as well.

Right now the thing is too fresh and I don't know what I am going to do, but I do feel that I have to make changes.  If nothing else, the psychological pressure of an ever-increasing amount of accumulating email is enormous... even on nights where I answered fifty letters, I would go away feeling guilty because I knew damn well that another month would pass before I found the energy to answer the next fifty, and during that month I'd fall another three or four hundred emails behind.

There were times early in my career when it felt as if I was publishing my books only to check them down a well.  Months and years would pass without me getting a single fan letter of any sort.  Maybe it's the memory of those days that has made me so appreciative of all the readers who have taken the time to write me about my books.

Even so, I can't go on the way that I was going.

comments.article:
As for fan mail: Would it work to hire someone to handle that? Since you're a big-time celebrity and all... :) Just because it has an 'e' in front of it doesn't mean it isn't fan mail...

comments.upictitle: Amanda The Kick Ass: Sailor Saturn
comments.article:
It might be best to have an email account set up for specifically for fans and another for personal/business affairs. You can get fairly reliable free accounts from hotmail, gmail, and yahoo. Also, it could be possible to set up a message board on your website for fans to post their correspondence.
Speaking from experience, AOL has a poor record for backing up saved items and you'd be better off copy-pasting materials you wish to save into Word and saving it to your hard drive.
I don't know if any of that made any sense, but I'm used to navigating my tech-illiterate mother through similar panics, so I'm confident that you will be fine.

Gmail really is a good thought. While it's still technically in "beta", that's the case for a lot of Google's excellent services -- they don't pull them out of "beta" before they're more bug-free than the vast majority of software that has gone "gold".

But we'd go a step further -- get Google Apps for your Domain so that you can get Gmail for your domain (basically, mail sent to addresses at georgerrmartin.com will go to Gmail servers, and you can respond to them via the Gmail interface with the from remaining
@georgerrmartin.com). This is what Linda and I use for our personal site, Hippoiathanatoi.com, and it works very nicely. We may end up moving Westeros.org to it as well, depending on some technical things. It would require some help from your Webmaster to change your domain records so that mail points to Gmail's servers (Gmail has extensive help files explaining this process, and Linda and I would be glad to help, having had prior experience).

With it, you can set up multiple e-mails for different purposes -- business, business proposals, friends, general contact, and so on -- and create various filters, labels (basically folders), and so on to help organize and prioritize your mail. You get excellent spam handling, too -- 99.999% of spam doesn't get through their spam filters. And because it has a web interface (although if you prefer Pop3 and downloading it directly to your own computer, you can do that, too), if you decide to move from personally answering all e-mail to having someone help you sort through it, they can access it pretty easily on-line and do that for you.

You might also drop the general contact address entirely, and find some other means by which fans can contact you. Robert Jordan uses his official blog, and you could similarly just use LJ to, say, solicit questions once per month and then post a response to a selected few as a separate post. Stephen R. Donaldson's gradual interview is a very interesting approach, basically doing something like our So Spake Martin collection but in an official way, which means more published responses that hopefully help to curtail redundant questions. Wouldn't be that hard to implement something like that at Westeros, using our content management system, and fold it seamlessly into the SSM Collection...

Regardless, whatever you do, you should set up some sort of Contact page on your website -- either to list several public addresses for various kinds of queries, or to just be your one address -- which provides pointers to various resources (yes, the Ice and Fire board, the Concordance, the So Spake Martin collection, and so on) fans with questions might consider going to to get answers to their questions before they hazard mailing you.

comments.article: Perhaps an intern?  Or a secretary?
I'm guessing mere mention of it would cause a deluge of applications.

You could keep your email private and use things like LiveJournal to interact with your readers. It would make things much easier. I don't see how you can keep up with that much email. You are only human after all.

Another thought is that you could maybe have the Fire and Ice messageboard create a special section for interactions or something like that. It's a thought.

:)

It seems to me that these ideas lack one thing that email doesn't: Privacy. And I don't know how big of a deal that really is, but I think it's likely that there are people who are less likely to gush about how much they love a person's work if the entire internet is on hand to hear about it.

I don't know.

comments.article:
I am really sorry that your emails are gone. I'd hate to lose all the mails I have saved too. Ran does have the SSM*, something I thought was always undervalued. So not all of those thoughtful replies of yours and fans are lost if that helps any. I agree with aergern on his point about the volume of mail as well - its simply not possible to keep up with that much mail. I'm not sure if you'd want to interact with people on the board because that could be a huge timesink too. Hell, the whole internet can be a timesink. :p I hope something gets worked out.

* http://www.westeros.org/Citadel/SSM/

I find it very moving, and in some ways reaffirming, how concerned about something as simple and mundane as fanmail you are. The fact that a famous author with a busy life can still take time to answer even a few of the letters is a good thing as is the concern for those left unanswered.

You could open a new account with a free--or paid--email server and keep it public for use with your fans, and another for private and business use.

It may be a difficult decision, but don't accept fan e-mail. Get a new e-mail account and use it for business and correspondence exclusively.

Knowing that you have thousands of unanswered e-mails niggling your mind is an unnecessary burden.

Your books have enriched my life and that of many readers. Your fans don't wish to repay you with psychological clutter and guilt.

Cut fan e-mail loose and feel free.

Some other authors have the policy of not answering emails, if you want to send him mail you need to send a letter C/O their publishing company, with a self addressed stamped envelope to reply in. It may be a little less convenient, but I think it might save time.

I bet a good deal of those 1998 emails would bounce anyway because people have changed their mail address. I know I have (no, I didn't write to you, bad me, lol). I have 5 emails addies but none dates back further than 2002 - after I gave up on Eudora and Pegasus that cluttered my drive and switched to yahoo and the mail that comes with my domain. In times of anything computer and intenet related progressing with almost light speed, I'm sure I'm not the only one who has changed her email. :)

Like some other commenters, I suggest different emails for private, publishing related and fan business; preferably by different providers (yahoo, google, whatever). Also, a disclaimer on your website that you read all emails but don't have the time to personally respond to every one, might help. People should understand, and if they don't, it's not your fault.

The lost bookmarks - now, that sucks. And reminds me to copy mine someplace safe.

A lot of people are suggesting a web based service for email. I agree with that completely, not only is the mail safely stored if something goes wrong. Well as safe as it can be.

Also when you change computers its still accessible, no need to port it over to another one. As long as you have an internet connection you can use it anywhere on any machine.

Like some of the others I would recommend Gmail.

As for the real crux of your entry. Well the ideal thing would be to learn not to have such a huge conscience. It is not humanly possible to respond to everyone.

Perhaps only respond to old fashioned letters that fans send and forget email.
comments.subject: Web mail

comments.article:
I second everything about Gmail and would like to add that it gives you free POP3 access to your email so if you feel more comfortable using an email program stored on your computer, you can still use one. This way you have your email the way you're used to AND a backup on the net, which you can re-download at any time on your PC if anything bad happens (though your outgoing mail would only be stored locally).

Also, Gmail has a great spam filter. The only caveat is that it's maximum size is 2 gigabytes so if you're used to have thousands of emails, some with attachments, in your inbox, it could easily overflow.

Well, fortunately, we live in a world where we can't rewind.

Though, you may not be able to imagine how this might be a positive thing in this particular situation, I take it as an opportunity to tell you this...

That there are those of us who write to you not because we demand or expect a response, but because we want you to know just how much we appreciate what it is that you do. comments.subject: No remote...

comments.article:
I think in this day and age, knowing that you have so many fans, many people do not expect a response, and are happy to know that they have an efficient way to send fanmail. ^_^

Author Neil Gaiman (http://www.neilgaiman.com/journal/) has a blog system where he answers certain emails (that have piqued his interest) every couple of days. This way, unless the contents of the letter are extremely personal, he can share information with all of his fans--it cuts down the amount of repeated questions. Also, it puts the pressure off of him having to answer all of the emails. I believe he has an assistant who pre-screens the emails for repeated subjects and the such. This system gives him more time to work on his books, and the fans seem to love it.

Just so everyone knows, http://westeros.org/ has an archive of questions and emails that GRRM has answered, so if you're just dying to send him an email asking him who Jon Snow's parents really are, you should really check there first. http://asoiaf.westeros.org/, the message board, also has a lot of information and a lot of ASOIAF related questions.
Now I'm REALLY flattered that you replied to my email, even if it was only two sentences (I made it easy!). Sorry for the loss.

I have no idea what actually happened to your "filing cabinet", but one thing that happened to me with similar symptoms is that my profile information got corrupted. What this does is to cause Windows to create a new user profile and seemingly all information is gone. All the old info is still there and you just need to make Windows go back to the old profile (MS knowledgebase has a page on this but I don't have the link handy). I guess if your data is still on the disk however, you would at least have found it with the help of these computer friends of yours but it might be worth a try. You need to be logged in as a user with administrative rights in order to find all files, so if you were searching for your files as a non-admin user you won't have been able to see the data you lost if the profile problem had occurred.

Just a thought...
/Johan
comments.subject: Idea for what might be wrong

comments.article:
A lot of people on here have suggested gmail, which is sensible. However, not everyone gets on with this and you may well be more comfortable staying with a different way of accessing your email. Also ANY email service is prone to lose messages (or have you accidentally delete them) once in a while.

What I suggest is this. Get a gmail account and set up your main email so that every email you get AND every email you send is automatically forwarded to your gmail account as well. Then you don't *use* your gmail but it is there as an emergency backup in case the worst happens or in case you want to find an email you've deleted but which has become relevant again.

I've been using this system for years now and it's great -- I only keep about a thousand or so emails in my main system and every email I ever receive is in my gmail. Gmail has good search facilities so unless you can remember almost nothing about a message you want ("Oh, I can't find that message from that guy a few months ago, what was he called, what did he want?") then you can find the message easily.

Another reason to recommend this rather than moving directly to "just" using gmail is that moving email address is MUCH more traumatic than moving postal address because it takes an age for people to update email address books.

Unfortunately, it's hard for me to advise you quite how to set this up because how to do it varies from system to system.

For old e-mails (that are more than 1 year old), remember that :
- probably the sender is not expecting an answer anymore
- probably some questions/subjects are not as much relevant to the sender as they were
- maybe the sender has changed his e-mail address (spending time on an answer would be a waste of time)

So I think you should have some kind of semi-automatic (pre-writen) anwers for old e-mails where you would explain that you would have liked to answer but that you lack time, and for the above reasons, you won't answer to mails that are getting too old. Suggest the fan can send another "updated" e-mail if he really feels it's worth it. Well, I don't know how to put it but you get the idea. You could also have two pre-written answers :
- one for old mails you won't answer
- one for old mails you keep and will try to answer
At least it will "ping" the sender e-mail address, and you'll detect e-mails to delete.

The only other solution I see is the contrary : if you want to answer to all those emails, then admit it and spend the necessary time to do it. In the beginning of februray, don't start working on ADWD before you've answered all the fan e-mails from january you want to answer. Don't answer to mails from februry but do it in the beginning of march, etc. It means less time to write books, but if you really feel psychological pressure on the subject, one full day spent to write mail is not "lost" if you really feel better afterwards. Of course, if it would require one week rather than one day per month, I suppose it wouldn't be viable.

As others, I'd also suggest having one e-mail for fans and another for more personal and business subjects.

Good luck with your mail, ADWD and your other projects !

I have a feeling that this is something that any successful author has to deal with after a while (not the losing email, but the mountain of unanswered email). I suppose that you could take consolation that it has been taken out of your hands and that you don't have to feel guilty about the unanswered mail (or be forced to make an announcement like this, for that matter).

comments.subject: Terry Pratchett

comments.article:
Lot of people have made practical suggestions, so I don't have to add to the chorus.

Let me just say one thing: your appreciation of your readers speaks extremely well of you. As does your regret about losing those unanswered mails.

Interestingly, my wife and I talked about just this yesterday. (I won't bore you with the details.) The last lines of your post here address precisely a problem that I currently have (new novelist, how to deal with reader apathy), and I thank you for this post.

(I'd like to take the opportunity to also thank you for Wild Cards, but that's on a different dance sheet entirely.)

Two things that stand out to me from your recent ordeal. First, I'm very pleased that you consider responding to fan mail so important--I've never written you (and likely won't), but I'll never forget the response letter I got when I was a kid from an author I had written, and I'd imagine many fans would feel the same to get a response from you. However, I want to echo the prevailing sentiment--while a response would be cherished, it's probably not why fans write to you. Knowing you read fan letters is probably connection enough.

Second, I think the way you process email could use some streamlining, and for that I recommend moving to the Getting Things Done (GTD) system. I never received the volume of email I'm sure you do, but my inbox has been saved by doing this. The premise is that whenever you read email, you have a few choices--you can respond immediately with a letter taking less than 2 minutes to write; you must respond to it as soon as possible, but the letter/action will take a while to craft; you must respond, but you have to wait until another event happens; you can archive it; you can delete it. In my email account, I have three folders to accommodate this--Action, Hold, Archive. Several times a day, I open my email, and evaluate each letter as I get it by first asking "Do I need to respond to this?" then "Can I respond to it quickly right now?" If it gets moved to the Action folder, I set aside time every day to work through as many emails as possible, and then if it sits for over a week I re-evaluate if it needs to be responded to, and what might be preventing me from doing that (if anything). Email, contrary to popular belief, is rarely urgent--you might also feel more free if you say "I will check my email only after 3 pm," or something to that effect, so the thought of unresponded emails isn't weighing you down while doing other work.

If you would like to go to this system for processing new email (and really, the evaporation of your old emails is a perfect opportunity to try something new), I suggest reading these articles at 43Folders, a GTD website--

http://www.43folders.com/izero/

as well as this article linked at Lifehacker--

http://www.lifehacker.com/software/tag/getting-things-done-with-gmail-102158.php

If you're interested in the book this all came from (which deals with a lot more than just email), it's here: http://www.davidco.com/

If you're still reading this, I'm impressed, and thanks for just looking at what I have to say. :)
comments.subject: Getting Things Done + Email

comments.article:
Hullo!
You could get an email address for private use, and have another to which your fans could send their mail. And if you want, you could get an email specifically for your business partners.
And to make sure that only those people send messages to the addresses they are meant to send things to, you could use a client that blocks any mail it does not know… Of course you’d have to feed it all the addresses you want it to accept first.
I think that this would be a good idea in your case. Having 3000 e-letters in a mailbox is a huge thing, and losing them all is… well. Obviously not good. Doing it this way will take a good week’s dedication, but it might be worth it.
I think it’s great that you answer your fan mail, but still. You are human and all know that there are certain priorities in each individual’s life. I’d rather lose a letter from a fan than a letter with a deadline. >.<
Hopefully you’ll get the problem fixed some time.
Good luck!

comments.upictitle: Impervious horrors of a leeward shore: smile
comments.article:
Make your computer Guru to build you new IT system...

You definitely need something like outside e-mail server, probably with IMAP support (messages are kept on the server). Several mail accounts for different purposes as was mentioned above.

Good spam filtering on fan account.

On your local system - some automatic backup procedure that keep your data safe.

Etc

But

Don't try to think about it yourself. Find a good expert, pay him and let him solve your problems once and for long.

You can consider to buy new hardware too. So you can work on old system till your new one is set up completely.

I second this. Hell, I bet some people would do it for free just to say "I built GRRM's backup system."

Also: the issue with free services is that sometimes you get what you pay for. That's one of the reasons I pay for an email account - if it ever stops doing what I want it to, it's trivial to just switch providers (it all goes through my domain so I can just point my domain elsewhere, I'll never have to change emails again.)

Sometimes spending a little money is vastly worth it, and e-mail providers are extremely cheap. :)
